items.title: What if verification wasn't required?
items.content:
You'd design: Simpler loops, no acceptance criteria, just "do the task"
Why this fails: LLMs claim completion based on understanding, not actual testing
Hidden constraint revealed: Workflows ARE verification loops made explicit

items.title: The irreducible workflow
items.content:
Task -> Verify -> Persist -> Loop
Essential: The task-verify cycle
Everything else: Refinement for reliability and scale

items.title: All 6 task management approaches share INV-002
items.content: PRD-Driven, Kanban, Goal-Conditioned, Phase-Based, TodoWrite, TaskCreate all share: Fresh context > extended sessions. Same principle, different implementations.

items.title: How workflow complexity fails
items.content:
Single-shot: 100% oversight, low risk
Interactive: 80% oversight, manageable
Autonomous: 30% oversight, requires verification
Multi-agent: 10% oversight, requires coordination
Swarm: 1% oversight, requires infrastructure

Each level amplifies both success and failure.

items.title: Workflow Spectrum = CI/CD Pipeline
items.content:
Single-shot → Manual deployment
Interactive → Pair programming
Autonomous → Automated tests
Multi-agent → Microservices
Swarm → Kubernetes orchestration

If you've scaled CI/CD, you already understand workflow progression.

items.title: Steve Yegge's Gas Town
items.content: 10+ parallel agents. The Mayor orchestrates, Polecats execute, Refinery validates. "Factory-scale" AI development. Required: Stage 7+ developer, significant infrastructure.

items.title: Why JSON over Markdown?
items.content:
ROOT: LLMs interpret text probabilistically
-> Markdown checkboxes get mangled
-> State becomes ambiguous
-> Automation breaks
-> Human intervention needed
-> JSON parsing is deterministic = reliable

items.title: Task Management Understanding
items.content:
Beginner: "Which format?" -> JSON (deterministic)
Intermediate: "Why PRD?" -> External state persistence
Advanced: "When phases?" -> Dependencies + milestones
Staff: "TaskCreate vs prd.json?" -> Multi-agent vs single
Expert: "Cross-pattern?" -> PRD = Gas Town inbox

items.title: PRD-Driven vs Goal-Conditioned
items.content:
PRD-Driven: Structured, predictable, overhead
Goal-Conditioned: Flexible, less overhead, harder to debug

Heuristic: >3 tasks = PRD. <3 tasks = goal-conditioned.

items.title: TodoWrite + prd.json
items.content:
Works? Yes, layered
prd.json: Project-level tasks (persistent)
TodoWrite: Iteration-level subtasks (ephemeral)
Benefit: Two granularities of tracking

items.title: If you skip typecheck
items.content:
IF: Skip typecheck in acceptance criteria
THEN: Type errors slip into commits
THEN: Future iterations inherit broken types
THEN: Errors compound faster than learnings
FINALLY: Entire PRD blocked by type cascades

Typecheck is non-negotiable. Priority 1 for a reason.

items.title: What if browser verification wasn't needed?
items.content:
You'd design: Just run tests, skip visual checks
Why this fails: Tests pass, but the UI is visually broken
Hidden constraint revealed: DOM structure != visual correctness

items.title: Wes Winder's Playwright Stack
items.content: Opus 4.5 + Ralph + Playwright = "Production-grade". Visual verification caught bugs that unit tests missed. "Claude's tendency to mark features complete without proper testing" -- Anthropic

items.title: Verification investment perception
items.content:
Iteration 1: "Verification feels slow"
Iteration 5: "Catching bugs early"
Iteration 15: "Verification is why late iterations work"
Iteration 30: "This is quality compounding"

Don't judge verification overhead by iteration 2.

items.title: When progress.txt flips from help to hurt
items.content:
0-10KB: Pure benefit (learnings compound)
10-20KB: Diminishing returns
20-30KB: Neutral (reading cost = thinking benefit)
30KB+: Net negative (context wasted)

THE INFLECTION: ~20KB

items.title: Why external state is mandatory
items.content:
ROOT: Fresh context = no memory
-> Progress must persist somewhere
-> Files are the only option
-> prd.json tracks tasks
-> progress.txt tracks learnings
-> Git tracks code
-> CLAUDE.md tracks project context

items.title: At 50+ iterations, reading state costs more than thinking
items.content:
progress.txt compounds. What started as useful memory becomes drag. The pattern that helps at iteration 5 hurts at iteration 50.

Threshold: ~20KB progress.txt, ~50 iterations

items.title: External Memory = Database + Cache
items.content:
Git commits → Database (permanent)
prd.json → Application state
progress.txt → Cache (needs pruning)
CLAUDE.md → Configuration

If you've designed caching systems, you understand progress.txt management.

items.title: Multi-Agent Understanding
items.content:
Beginner: "When parallel?" -> Independent features
Intermediate: "How coordinate?" -> Worktrees or TaskCreate
Advanced: "Hub vs peer?" -> Central vs distributed control
Staff: "Assembly line?" -> When stages are specialized
Expert: "Swarm?" -> Factory-scale, 10+ agents

items.title: Parallel Ralph + CC Mirror
items.content:
Works? Yes, complementary
Parallel Ralph: Isolation via worktrees
CC Mirror: Coordination via TaskCreate
Combined: True isolation + dependency awareness

items.title: UNSOLVED: Optimal agent count
items.content: How many agents before coordination overhead dominates execution? 3? 5? 10? Varies by project complexity, team experience, infrastructure. No formula yet.

items.title: Molly Cantillon's Personal Panopticon
items.content: 8 parallel Claude instances. Different domains: health, finance, social, learning. "Human as observer of multiple agents." Jmail built with 18M users overnight.

items.title: If you skip max iterations
items.content:
IF: No max iterations set
THEN: Stuck loop runs indefinitely
THEN: Token costs spiral
THEN: No useful output
FINALLY: Wake up to $100+ bill, zero progress

Always set --max-iterations. Even 100 is better than unlimited.

items.title: Context Rot vs. Memory Loss
items.content:
Extended session: Rich context, but quality degrades at 80K
Fresh context: Peak quality, but must reconstruct state

No perfect answer. Accept fresh > rot. Invest in better memory hygiene.

items.title: How task sizing fails
items.content:
XS-S tasks: Safe, low risk
M tasks: Balanced, judgment required
L tasks: Risk of context pressure
XL tasks: Context overflow, broken output

The danger zone is invisible until you're in it.

items.title: What if task decomposition was easy?
items.content:
You'd have: Clear formulas, predictable sizing
Why this fails: Cognitive load varies by codebase, patterns, dependencies
Hidden constraint revealed: Decomposition is a skill, not a formula

items.title: If autonomous isn't right
items.content:
Need parallelism? -> CC Mirror
Need human gates? -> HOTL Ralph
Need debugging? -> Interactive session
Need exploration? -> Single Claude
Need content, not code? -> Ralph Marketer

items.title: How workflow choice perception changes
items.content:
Day 1: "Autonomous seems risky"
Week 1: "Overnight features are amazing"
Month 1: "I can't go back to manual"
Month 3: "Workflow choice is my competitive advantage"

The risk is not trying autonomous. It's staying manual.

items.title: Workflow Selection Mastery
items.content:
Beginner: "Which workflow?" -> Start with interactive
Intermediate: "When autonomous?" -> Verifiable criteria
Advanced: "When parallel?" -> Independent features
Staff: "When swarm?" -> Enterprise scale
Expert: "Workflow composition?" -> HOTL + parallel + phases

items.title: Ryan Carson: 14 iterations, $10-15
items.content: Untangle Legal Agent. 6 user stories, ran overnight. "Learnings compound. By story 10, Ralph knew our patterns." The progress.txt paid off in later iterations.
